awd_titl_txt: Establishing Molecular Links Within a Systems-level Model of the Drosophila Sleep Homeostat
awd_abstract_narration:
Non-technical abstract

The intense sleep need felt the day following a night of sleeplessness is familiar to many. The build-up of this need is often urgent because sleep is crucial to many essential physiological processes including learning, memory formation and tissue repair. The increased sleep need is generated in the brain, presumably by a collection of neurons inter-connected via complex electrical and biochemical signals. This system of connected neurons is collectively known as the sleep homeostat. But despite the homeostat's central role in controlling sleep, very little is known about its structure, composition, and principles of operation. This research will construct a functional architecture of the homeostat by taking advantage of the fruit fly that, like humans, exhibits sleep but, owing to its relative simplicity offers a tractable system in which to dissect the homeostat. The proposed studies will develop a new series of genetic tools that will allow precise and controllable manipulations of the neurons and the interconnecting pathways suspected of forming the sleep homeostat. The experiments will be guided by a novel computational model developed by the PI. Results from the studies will constitute the first computational-molecular model of the sleep homeostat and will likely give rise to new testable hypotheses about the regulation of sleep-wake cycles. The interplay of mathematical modeling and genetics in the project will offer unique opportunities in interdisciplinary research and coursework for undergraduate and graduate students, with particular emphasis on involving members traditionally underrepresented in the sciences.   


Technical abstract

This work will establish a model of the sleep homeostat, a feedback system that adjusts future sleep need based on past sleep, which is both mathematically rigorous and molecularly tractable. The project will exploit the fruit fly to build upon a recently developed theoretical model that suggests that four core biochemical pathways constitute the homeostat of the insect. Parameters of the model predict that neuromodulators such as dopamine and short neuropeptide F describe these pathways. A combination of behavioral, genetic and computational approaches will be employed to link the theoretical parameters to the neuromodulators, thus establishing the first quantitative model of the sleep homeostat with well-defined molecular identities. Objective 1 will examine the sleep-wake dynamics over- or under-expressing candidate neuromodulators to rapidly generate a short-list of neuromodulator pathways. Objective 2 will then use the Gal4/UAS system to target the neuromodulator-producing neurons, biochemically perturbing them by altering the abundance of the short-listed substrates. Objective 3 will overexpress ion channels to electrically perturb specific neuromodulator-expressing neurons and serve as a third independent test in the identification of neuromodulators that underlie fly sleep homeostasis. Together, these studies will lead to a unified, computational-molecular model of the homeostat and, in so doing, substantially broaden our understanding of the neural mechanisms governing sleep. Additionally, the computational and molecular approaches taken in the research will be incorporated into laboratory experiences for students, thus training future scientists in how to integrate mathematical and molecular approaches in the study of nervous system functions.

por.por_cntn:
Sleep is pervasive in the animal world. But the amount of sleep and its distribution over time vary dramatically across species. For instance, while we sleep mostly at night for 7-8 hours at a time, giraffes nap sporadically for 1-2 minutes, accruing only about 1 hour of total sleep during a 24 hour period. Despite differences in overt sleep structure, all animals are thought to share the same biological control mechanisms of sleep---the circadian clock, that keeps internal physiological processes in synchrony with environmental changes and the sleep homeostat, that keeps track of the amount and quality of sleep. Together, the clock and the homeostat ensure members of a species receive the appropriate amount of sleep distributed properly over time. How do the internal controllers achieve this task? The question has proven to be challenging to answer, particularly because very little is known about the structure, composition, and principles of operation of the homeostat. The broad aim of this project was thus to improve our understanding of sleep regulation, with emphasis on the homeostat.  The project accomplished this by developing a quantitative model of the sleep homeostat, developing advanced college-level coursework in biological physics, offering authentic research opportunities for undergraduate and doctoral trainees, giving scientific seminars, and publishing peer-reviewed research articles.

The studies were done in the fruit fly that, like humans, exhibits sleep but, owing to its relative simplicity offers a tractable system in which to investigate the homeostat. By combing through a large set of sleep recordings, we were able to mathematically isolate and describe in some detail an important function of the homeostat---to generate sleep pressure. Sleep pressure can be intense and is signal that there is a need for make-up sleep. It is felt as increasing drowsiness, fatigue, headache, usually during the day following a night of sleeplessness.  Analyses of the sleep recordings also produced a statistical description of how flies transition between the strikingly different states of sleep and wake. This description includes inputs from the homeostat, the circadian clock, and environmental lights. To assess and improve the quantitative model, we mechanically sleep-deprived flies with normal sleep regulation and flies that were known to have dysfunctional homeostat. We also genetically turned off or hyperexcited specific groups of neurons in the fly brain to establish connections between molecular substrates of sleep and the mathematical constructs representing sleep regulation. Additionally, results from the project lent themselves to two fortuitous sleep-related studies. One study, where we asked how sleep might be altered if flies were given a choice of color lights during the day, showed that such choices can increase daytime sleep. Even more unexpectedly, the data revealed that color preference is not static in animals but instead it changes with the time of day. In another study, we and collaborators asked what happens to sleep if flies are deprived of social interactions. Our analyses showed that social isolation caused flies to sleep more in the morning and, intriguingly, altered their brain state such that it mimics the brain of a starved individual.   

The interplay of mathematical modeling, genetics and behavioral experiments offered unique opportunities in interdisciplinary research and coursework to undergraduate, graduate, and post-doctoral trainees. As part of this project, the PI developed a course in biological physics drawing upon ideas from physics to provide quantitative explanations of biological systems. This course, the first of its kind on campus, engaged students from disparate disciplines such as physics, neuroscience, chemistry, and computer science. After a few trial runs, the course became a permanent offering in the undergraduate curriculum and most recently, formed the core of a new biological physics minor being offered by the University. Top-performing students from the classroom were recruited to participate in laboratory research, working side by side with doctoral students and mentored by the PI. Most of the dozen or so undergraduates who participated in the project’s research are now pursuing graduate studies in computational neuroscience, biophysics, biochemistry or are training to be physicians. The project also formed the basis for four doctoral studies---half of these trainees are continuing in academic tracks while the other half have joined the workforce. Scientific findings emanating from the project were shared with the wider community through multiple presentations at local, national and international meetings and through articles in widely-read scientific journals.
